Federal Court
von Finckenstein, J.
May 10, 2005.
Counsel:
Deanna Okun-Nachoff, for the applicant;
Helen Park, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Deanna Okun-Nachoff, Vancouver, British Columbia, for the applicant;
John H. Sims, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.

[1]
von Finckenstein, J.
: The Applicant arrived in Canada under the Live-in Caregiver Program ("LCP") on November 25, 2002 from the Philippines. She has been trying to secure permanent resident status for herself, her husband and their 10 year old daughter. Her husband and daughter remain in the Philippines and she has been separated from them for approximately two years while she has worked in Canada.

[2]
The Applicant worked for her sister from the day she arrived in Canada until March 31, 2003. The Applicant found a new employer and began working for Ms. Melinda and Mr. de Lara on April 14, 2003. She worked for them until February 28, 2004. Her work permit did not expire until April 13, 2004. In March of 2004, the Applicant found another employer, Ms. Grelish who registered her name with the Domestic Workers' Registry. Ms. Grelish then submitted her Application for Foreign Live-In Caregiver to Human Resources and Development Canada ("HRDC").

[3]
Ms. Grelish did not, however, obtain a confirmation from HRDC because she did not put her home address on the application form. She also decided mid-way through the application process that the Applicant should work for her parents instead. In order for the Applicant to work for Ms. Grelish's father, it was necessary to re-register the Applicant's name with the Domestic Workers' Registry and submit a new Application for Foreign Live-In Caregiver to HRDC. When Mr. Grelish received a new confirmation letter from HRDC, the Applicant immediately sent in her application for a new work permit with a receipt for the $150.00 fee. When she sent in her application on June 23, 2004, her permit had been expired for 71 days.

[4]
She received a letter from Citizenship and Immigration Canada ("CIC") dated July 24, 2004 that said her application for a work permit had been refused because she had not applied for restoration with the appropriate fees. CIC did not notify her during the two week period when she still could have submitted a restoration application that she could do so if she sent in the $200.00 restoration fee.

[5]
The Applicant now seeks judicial review of that decision arguing that procedural fairness dictates that the Applicant should have been provided with an opportunity to perfect her application, i.e. apply for restoration of the temporary residence status as well as applying for renewal of the work permit, thereby extending her status under the LCP.

[6]
It is undisputed that the standard of review for decisions of visa officers is reasonableness simpliciter (see  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> .

[7]
Live-in caregivers must first obtain a work visa to enter Canada and once in Canada on a work authorization, they are considered temporary residents. They can apply for permanent residence in Canada after they have worked for two years as live-in caregivers, within three years of their arrival in Canada.

[8]
A worker can extend their work permit by applying for an extension before the expiry of their term (see s. 181 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, SOR/2002-227 (the "Regulations")). If an individual has lost their status, they can apply for a restoration of status within 90 days of the expiry of their term (see s. 182 of the Regulations).

[9]
An applicant failing to obtain the extension has to return to her homeland and start the process all over again. No credit under the LCP will be given for time already spent in Canada. In addition, the time for processing in the Philippines for an application under the LCP program is about two years, thus sending a caregiver back, merely for failing to check a box and remit $200.00 is quite draconian.

[10]
This case is nearly identical with  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  where I stated at paragraph 29:
Applying common sense to this process, the date of receipt of the application, i.e. May 25, 2004, should be considered the lock-in date. Clearly she did not know, (nor could she reasonably be expected to know from the Extension Booklet,) that she also had to apply for a restoration of status. The Applicant should have been advised to check Box D and to send another $200.00 all within 19 days (the time remaining in the 90 day grace period). This was all that was required. Instead, CIC mechanically applied section 12 of the Regulations, ruling the application out of time. In my view, this is neither consistent with common sense, nor with Choi, supra.

[11]
Coincidentally, in this case the application was also received on the 71st day of the 90-day grace period set out in s. 182 of the Regulations. Therefore, applying the reasoning of Lim, supra to this cases mutatis mutandis, June 23, 2004 should be considered the lock-in date. The Applicant did not know, (nor could she reasonably be expected to know from the Extension Booklet), that she also had to apply for a restoration of status. The Applicant should have been advised to check Box D and to send another $200.00, all within 19 days (the time remaining in the 90-day grace period). Common sense and consistency with Choi [1992] ICF 763 dictates proceeding in such a way.

[12]
Accordingly, this application will be allowed.
ORDER

[13]
THIS COURT ORDERS
that the decision dated July 27, 2004, of the Vegreville Centre of CIC, is set aside. The matter is returned to the Vegreville Centre of CIC to be dealt with in accordance with the terms of paragraph 11 of the Reasons for Order above.
[End of document]

statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, SOR/2002-227 (the "Regulations") s. 181
Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, SOR/2002-227 (the "Regulations") s. 182
legal_issues: The extent to which immigration authorities have a duty to inform applicants of all requirements for maintaining temporary resident status.

Whether a strict application of statutory deadlines for immigration applications is reasonable in circumstances where an applicant acted promptly upon receiving notice of a deficiency, but was not informed of all available remedies.
The appropriate standard of review for immigration decisions concerning temporary resident status and work permits.
Whether an application date should be considered a 'lock-in' date for purposes of restoration of temporary resident status, even if the applicant was unaware of the restoration requirement.
The procedural fairness obligations owed to applicants for temporary work permits when their applications are refused due to failure to meet all requirements.
factual_background: An individual arrived in Canada from the Philippines on November 25, 2002, under the Live-in Caregiver Program (LCP).
The individual intended to sponsor her husband and 10-year-old daughter for permanent residency.
The individual was separated from her husband and daughter for approximately two years while working in Canada.
Initial employment was with a family member from the date of arrival until March 31, 2003.
Subsequent employment began on April 14, 2003, with Ms. Melinda and Mr. de Lara, and continued until February 28, 2004.
A work permit was valid until April 13, 2004.
In March 2004, the individual secured a new employer, Ms. Grelish, who registered her with the Domestic Workers' Registry.
Ms. Grelish submitted an application for a foreign live-in caregiver to HRDC but did not include a home address.
Ms. Grelish intended to transfer employment to her parents, requiring re-registration and a new HRDC application.
A new confirmation letter was received from HRDC, and the individual submitted a work permit application on June 23, 2004, 71 days after the previous permit expired.
On July 24, 2004, Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) refused the work permit application due to a lack of a restoration application and associated fees.
CIC did not inform the applicant of the option to submit a restoration application with the required fee during the 90-day period.
The applicant sought judicial review of the CIC decision.

Applicants: Procedural fairness dictates the Applicant should have been given the opportunity to perfect her application by applying for restoration of temporary resident status.
The Applicant was not notified that she could apply for restoration of status by submitting the $200.00 restoration fee during the two-week period she could have done so.

The date of receipt of the application (June 23, 2004) should be considered the 'lock-in' date, and she should have been advised to apply for restoration within the remaining 19 days of the 90-day grace period.
The Applicant reasonably did not know she needed to apply for restoration of status in addition to renewing her work permit, as this was not clear from the Extension Booklet.
Refusing to credit time already spent in Canada for failing to check a box and remit $200.00 is draconian, given the two-year processing time for LCP applications in the Philippines.
Respondents: The Applicant’s work permit had expired 71 days before she submitted her application.
The Applicant’s application for a work permit was refused because she did not apply for restoration of status with the appropriate fees.
The Applicant failed to apply for an extension of her work permit before its expiry, and therefore had to return to her homeland and restart the process.
The application was out of time according to section 12 of the Regulations.

court_analysis: The court found that the Applicant's work permit application was improperly refused by Citizenship and Immigration Canada (CIC) due to a rigid application of regulations without consideration for procedural fairness and common sense.
The court relied on the standard of review of 'reasonableness simpliciter' for decisions of visa officers, indicating a deferential but not uncritical approach to the agency's decision.

The court interpreted sections 181 and 182 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, noting that while extensions require application *before* expiry, restoration of status is available within 90 days *after* expiry. The core issue was the failure to inform the applicant of the restoration option.

The court determined that the Applicant's application, received on the 71st day of the 90-day restoration period, should be considered a 'lock-in' date, meaning the application was effectively made within the allowable timeframe if the applicant had been properly informed of the restoration requirement.

The court reasoned that the Applicant could not reasonably be expected to know she needed to apply for both an extension *and* restoration, particularly given the information available in the Extension Booklet. The court found it illogical to penalize the applicant with a complete loss of accrued time under the Live-in Caregiver Program for a relatively minor oversight (failing to check a box and pay a $200 fee).

The court explicitly relied on its prior decision in *Lim* (a nearly identical case) and applied the same reasoning *mutatis mutandis*, emphasizing the importance of common sense and consistency with the *Choi* precedent.

The court concluded that CIC’s mechanical application of the regulations was inconsistent with both common sense and established jurisprudence, and therefore set aside the refusal decision, ordering CIC to reconsider the application in light of the court’s findings.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review was allowed.
The decision dated July 27, 2004, of the Vegreville Centre of CIC, was set aside.
The matter was returned to the Vegreville Centre of CIC to be dealt with in accordance with paragraph 11 of the Reasons for Order.
